Data Broker Is Selling Location Data of People Who Visit Abortion Clinics4/5/2022

It costs just over $160 to get a week's worth of data on where people who visited Planned Parenthood came from, and where they went afterwards.

class="article__body-components"><div class="topic-callout"><div class="topic-callout__img"><a href="https://www.vice.com/en/topic/cyber"><img src="https://video-images.vice.com/topics/57a205628cb727dec795a6b1/callout_logo/1614199980283-screen-shot-2021-02-24-at-34918-pm.png?resize=240:*" alt="Screen Shot 2021-02-24 at 3"/></a></div><div class="topic-callout__dek">Hacking. Disinformation. Surveillance. CYBER is Motherboard's podcast and reporting on the dark underbelly of the internet.</div><div class="topic-callout__cta"><a href="https://www.vice.com/en/topic/cyber">See More </a></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>A location data firm is selling information related to visits to clinics that provide abortions including Planned Parenthood facilities, showing where groups of people visiting the locations came from, how long they stayed there, and where they then went afterwards, according to sets of the data purchased by Motherboard.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The data sale is obviously more important in the <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2022/05/02/supreme-court-abortion-draft-opinion-00029473" target="_blank"><span>context of a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion</span></a> in which Justice Alito indicated that the court is ready to repeal the decision in <em>Roe v. Wade</em>, the decades-old precedent that has provided federal protections to those seeking an abortion. If that draft does become a formal decision, it would immediately fully or partly ban abortion rights in at least <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/5dgxzb/states-that-will-ban-abortion"><span>13 states</span></a>.</p></span><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-shortform-top"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p><a href="https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2022/02/meet-abortion-bans-new-best-friend-your-phone/" target="_blank"><span>How data collecting intersects with abortion rights, or the lack thereof</span></a>, is likely to gather more attention in the wake of the draft. The country may also see an increase in vigilante activity or forms of surveillance and harassment against those seeking or providing abortions. With this aggregated location data available to anyone on the open market, customers could include anti-abortion vigilantes as well. Anti-abortion groups are already fairly adept at using novel technology for their goals. In 2016, an advertising CEO who worked with anti-abortion and Christian groups <a href="https://rewirenewsgroup.com/article/2016/05/25/anti-choice-groups-deploy-smartphone-surveillance-target-abortion-minded-women-clinic-visits/" target="_blank"><span>sent targeted advertisements to women sitting in Planned Parenthood clinics</span></a> in an attempt to change their decision around getting an abortion. The sale of the location data raises questions around why companies are selling data based on abortion clinics specifically, and whether they should introduce more safeguards around the purchase of that information, if be selling it at all.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>“It's bonkers dangerous to have abortion clinics and then let someone buy the census tracks where people are coming from to visit that abortion clinic,” Zach Edwards, a cybersecurity researcher who closely tracks the data selling marketplace, told Motherboard in an online chat after reviewing the data. “This is how you dox someone traveling across state lines for abortions—how you dox clinics providing this service.”</p></span><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-shortform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span><blockquote data-component="QuoteBlock" class="abc__quote abc__quote--blockquote"><p><em><strong>Do you work in the location data industry or how know else the data is being used? We'd love to hear from you. Using a non-work phone or computer, you can contact Joseph Cox securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, Wickr on josephcox, OTR chat on <a href="mailto:jfcox@jabber.ccc.de">jfcox@jabber.ccc.de</a>, or email <a href="mailto:joseph.cox@vice.com">joseph.cox@vice.com</a>.</strong></em></p></blockquote><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>In the wake of a near-total abortion ban in Texas, for example, people in Texas seeking abortions have increasingly had to travel to other states where abortion access is easier to get the care they need. With <em>Roe</em> set to fall, people seeking abortions who live in conservative states and can afford to are likely to start traveling to get an abortion. Location data could play into whether and how that travel is identified, making it even more urgent for regulators and lawmakers to consider how location data is collected, used, and sold.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>The company selling the data is SafeGraph. SafeGraph ultimately obtains location data from ordinary apps installed on peoples’ phones. Often app developers install code, called software development kits (SDKs), into their apps that sends users’ location data to companies in exchange for the developer receiving payment. Sometimes app users don’t know that their phone—be that via a prayer app, or a weather app—is collecting and sending location data to third parties, let alone some of the more dangerous use cases that Motherboard has reported on, <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x"><span>including transferring data to U.S. military contractors</span></a>. Planned Parenthood is not the organization performing the data collection nor benefiting from it financially.</p></span><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-shortform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>SafeGraph then repackages that location data and other data into various products. On Tuesday <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/m7vymn/cdc-tracked-phones-location-data-curfews"><span>Motherboard reported that the CDC bought $420,000 worth of SafeGraph data</span></a> for a laundry list of COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 use cases. Google <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence"><span>banned SafeGraph from the Google Play Store in June</span></a>.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>SafeGraph classifies "Planned Parenthood" as a "brand" that can be tracked, and the data Motherboard purchased includes more than 600 Planned Parenthood locations in the United States. The data included a week's worth of location data for those locations in mid-April. SafeGraph calls the location data product “Patterns.” In total, the data cost just over $160. Not all Planned Parenthood locations offer abortion services. But Motherboard verified that some facilities included in the purchased dataset do. </p></span><div class="abc__article_embed" data-component="RelatedArticleBlock"><div class="vice-card vice-card--light"><div class="vice-card__content"><div class="vice-card-rubric vice-card-rubric--light vice-card__vice-card-rubric"><a class="vice-card-rubric__label vice-card-rubric__link" href="/en/section/tech">Tech</a></div><h3 class="vice-card-hed vice-card-hed--light vice-card__vice-card-hed"><a href="/en/article/m7vymn/cdc-tracked-phones-location-data-curfews" class="vice-card-hed__link">CDC Tracked Millions of Phones to See If Americans Followed COVID Lockdown Orders</a></h3><div class="vice-card-details vice-card-details--light vice-card__vice-card-details"><div class="vice-card-details__byline">Joseph Cox</div><time class="vice-card-details__pub-date" dateTime="2022-05-03T13:00">05.03.22</time></div></div><div class="vice-card-image vice-card__vice-card-image"><a href="/en/article/m7vymn/cdc-tracked-phones-location-data-curfews" class="vice-card-image__link" tabindex="-1"><div class="vice-card-image__placeholder-image placeholder-image--16-9--sm placeholder-image--16-9--md placeholder-image--16-9--lg"><div><picture class="responsive-image lazyloader--lazy"><source media="(min-width: 1000px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><source media="(min-width: 700px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><source media="(min-width: 0px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><img class="responsive-image__img" alt=""/></picture></div></div></a></div></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Motherboard also searched the SafeGraph website for “Family Planning,” which returned a relevant result of “Family Planning Centers” that people could then buy data related to.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>SafeGraph’s Patterns data aims to answer questions like “how often people visit, how long they stay, where they came from, where else they go, and more,” <a href="https://docs.safegraph.com/docs/monthly-patterns" target="_blank"><span>according to SafeGraph’s website</span></a>. SafeGraph calculates where it believes visitors to a location live to the census block level. SafeGraph does this by analyzing where a phone is commonly located overnight, <a href="https://docs.safegraph.com/docs/monthly-patterns#section-determining-home-location" target="_blank"><span>the company’s documentation suggests</span></a>.</p></span><span><div class="adph adph--border"><div class="ac-w-ph__dsc">Advertisement</div><div class="ac-w-ph"><div class="ph ph-shortform-scroll"><div class="vice-ad__container"><span class="vice-ad"></span></div></div></div></div></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>SafeGraph’s data is aggregated, meaning it isn’t explicitly specifying where a certain device moved to. Instead, it focuses on the movements of groups of devices. But researchers have repeatedly <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/srep01376" target="_blank"><span>warned about the possibilities of unmasking individuals</span></a> contained in allegedly anonymized datasets. </p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Sections of the SafeGraph dataset Motherboard purchased handle a very small number of devices per record, theoretically making deanonymization of those people easier. Some had just four or five devices visiting that location, with SafeGraph filtering the data by whether the person used an Android or an iOS device as well.</p></span><div class="abc__article_embed" data-component="RelatedArticleBlock"><div class="vice-card vice-card--light"><div class="vice-card__content"><div class="vice-card-rubric vice-card-rubric--light vice-card__vice-card-rubric"><a class="vice-card-rubric__label vice-card-rubric__link" href="/en/section/tech">Tech</a></div><h3 class="vice-card-hed vice-card-hed--light vice-card__vice-card-hed"><a href="/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence" class="vice-card-hed__link">Google Bans Location Data Firm Funded by Former Saudi Intelligence Head</a></h3><div class="vice-card-details vice-card-details--light vice-card__vice-card-details"><div class="vice-card-details__byline">Joseph Cox</div><time class="vice-card-details__pub-date" dateTime="2021-08-12T13:00">08.12.21</time></div></div><div class="vice-card-image vice-card__vice-card-image"><a href="/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence" class="vice-card-image__link" tabindex="-1"><div class="vice-card-image__placeholder-image placeholder-image--16-9--sm placeholder-image--16-9--md placeholder-image--16-9--lg"><div><picture class="responsive-image lazyloader--lazy"><source media="(min-width: 1000px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><source media="(min-width: 700px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><source media="(min-width: 0px)" srcSet="data://image/png;base64,"/><img class="responsive-image__img" alt=""/></picture></div></div></a></div></div></div><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>On the data showing where people traveled to a certain clinic based on their census block, potentially across state borders, Edwards said “SafeGraph is going to be the weapon of choice for anti-choice radicals attempting to target ‘out of state clinics’ providing medical care.” Missouri is considering a law to <a href="https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/missouri-considers-law-to-make-illegal-to-aid-or-abet-out-of-state" target="_blank"><span>make it illegal to “aid or abet” abortions in other states</span></a>.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Tracking visitors to abortion clinics has long been a staple in showing the threat posed by location data. In a 2018 investigation, <em><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/12/10/business/location-data-privacy-apps.html" target="_blank"><span>The New York Times </span></a></em><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/12/10/business/location-data-privacy-apps.html" target="_blank"><span>took location data and followed multiple people inside it</span></a>, and unmasked some of those. One of the people followed visited a Planned Parenthood facility, according to the report.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Recently, a Christian-focused outlet The Pillar published a piece that used location data to track the movements of a specific priest and then <a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/pkbxp8/grindr-location-data-priest-weaponization-app"><span>outed him publicly as potentially gay without his consent</span></a>.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p>Planned Parenthood did not respond to a request for comment. SafeGraph did not respond to a request for comment either, which included the specific question of whether the company would continue to sell location data related to abortion clinics.</p></span><span class="abc__textblock size--article" data-component="TextBlock"><p><em><strong>Subscribe to our cybersecurity podcast, <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/cyber/id1441708044?mt=2" target="_blank">CYBER</a>. Subscribe to <a href="https://www.twitch.tv/motherboardtv" target="_blank">our new Twitch channel</a>.</strong></em></p></span></div><div class="article__tagged"><div class="tags"><span type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"data":{"articles":[{"__typename":"Article","id":"627150b555fea0009bc2b1d5","body_components_json":"[{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556dda\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":0,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"A location data firm is selling information related to visits to clinics that provide abortions including Planned Parenthood facilities, showing where groups of people visiting the locations came from, how long they stayed there, and where they then went afterwards, according to sets of the data purchased by Motherboard.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":322,\"wordscount\":49,\"text\":\"A location data firm is selling information related to visits to clinics that provide abortions including Planned Parenthood facilities, showing where groups of people visiting the locations came from, how long they stayed there, and where they then went afterwards, according to sets of the data purchased by Motherboard.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556ddb\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":1,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"The data sale is obviously more important in the \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.politico.com/news/2022/05/02/supreme-court-abortion-draft-opinion-00029473\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003econtext of a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e in which Justice Alito indicated that the court is ready to repeal the decision in \u003cem\u003eRoe v. Wade\u003c/em\u003e, the decades-old precedent that has provided federal protections to those seeking an abortion. If that draft does become a formal decision, it would immediately fully or partly ban abortion rights in at least \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/5dgxzb/states-that-will-ban-abortion\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e13 states\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":630,\"wordscount\":104,\"text\":\"The data sale is obviously more important in the [context of a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion](https://www.politico.com/news/2022/05/02/supreme-court-abortion-draft-opinion-00029473) in which Justice Alito indicated that the court is ready to repeal the decision in _Roe v. Wade_, the decades-old precedent that has provided federal protections to those seeking an abortion. If that draft does become a formal decision, it would immediately fully or partly ban abortion rights in at least [13 states](https://www.vice.com/en/article/5dgxzb/states-that-will-ban-abortion).\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556ddc\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":2,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2022/02/meet-abortion-bans-new-best-friend-your-phone/\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHow data collecting intersects with abortion rights, or the lack thereof\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e, is likely to gather more attention in the wake of the draft. The country may also see an increase in vigilante activity or forms of surveillance and harassment against those seeking or providing abortions. With this aggregated location data available to anyone on the open market, customers could include anti-abortion vigilantes as well. Anti-abortion groups are already fairly adept at using novel technology for their goals. In 2016, an advertising CEO who worked with anti-abortion and Christian groups \u003ca href=\\\"https://rewirenewsgroup.com/article/2016/05/25/anti-choice-groups-deploy-smartphone-surveillance-target-abortion-minded-women-clinic-visits/\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003esent targeted advertisements to women sitting in Planned Parenthood clinics\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e in an attempt to change their decision around getting an abortion. The sale of the location data raises questions around why companies are selling data based on abortion clinics specifically, and whether they should introduce more safeguards around the purchase of that information, if be selling it at all.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":1251,\"wordscount\":189,\"text\":\"[How data collecting intersects with abortion rights, or the lack thereof](https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2022/02/meet-abortion-bans-new-best-friend-your-phone/), is likely to gather more attention in the wake of the draft. The country may also see an increase in vigilante activity or forms of surveillance and harassment against those seeking or providing abortions. With this aggregated location data available to anyone on the open market, customers could include anti-abortion vigilantes as well. Anti-abortion groups are already fairly adept at using novel technology for their goals. In 2016, an advertising CEO who worked with anti-abortion and Christian groups [sent targeted advertisements to women sitting in Planned Parenthood clinics](https://rewirenewsgroup.com/article/2016/05/25/anti-choice-groups-deploy-smartphone-surveillance-target-abortion-minded-women-clinic-visits/) in an attempt to change their decision around getting an abortion. The sale of the location data raises questions around why companies are selling data based on abortion clinics specifically, and whether they should introduce more safeguards around the purchase of that information, if be selling it at all.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556ddd\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":3,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"It's bonkers dangerous to have abortion clinics and then let someone buy the census tracks where people are coming from to visit that abortion clinic, Zach Edwards, a cybersecurity researcher who closely tracks the data selling marketplace, told Motherboard in an online chat after reviewing the data. This is how you dox someone traveling across state lines for abortionshow you dox clinics providing this service.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":420,\"wordscount\":67,\"text\":\"\u0026#x201c;It's bonkers dangerous to have abortion clinics and then let someone buy the census tracks where people are coming from to visit that abortion clinic,\u0026#x201d; Zach Edwards, a cybersecurity researcher who closely tracks the data selling marketplace, told Motherboard in an online chat after reviewing the data. \u0026#x201c;This is how you dox someone traveling across state lines for abortions\u0026#x2014;how you dox clinics providing this service.\u0026#x201d;\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556dde\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":4,\"role\":\"blockquote\",\"html\":\"\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDo you work in the location data industry or how know else the data is being used? With \u003cem\u003eRoe\u003c/em\u003e set to fall, people seeking abortions who live in conservative states and can afford to are likely to start traveling to get an abortion. Location data could play into whether and how that travel is identified, making it even more urgent for regulators and lawmakers to consider how location data is collected, used, and sold.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":549,\"wordscount\":96,\"text\":\"In the wake of a near-total abortion ban in Texas, for example, people in Texas seeking abortions have increasingly had to travel to other states where abortion access is easier to get the care they need. With _Roe_ set to fall, people seeking abortions who live in conservative states and can afford to are likely to start traveling to get an abortion. Location data could play into whether and how that travel is identified, making it even more urgent for regulators and lawmakers to consider how location data is collected, used, and sold.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de0\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":6,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"The company selling the data is SafeGraph. SafeGraph ultimately obtains location data from ordinary apps installed on peoples phones. Often app developers install code, called software development kits (SDKs), into their apps that sends users location data to companies in exchange for the developer receiving payment. Sometimes app users dont know that their phonebe that via a prayer app, or a weather appis collecting and sending location data to third parties, let alone some of the more dangerous use cases that Motherboard has reported on, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eincluding transferring data to U.S. military contractors\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. Planned Parenthood is not the organization performing the data collection nor benefiting from it financially.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":825,\"wordscount\":130,\"text\":\"The company selling the data is SafeGraph. SafeGraph ultimately obtains location data from ordinary apps installed on peoples\u0026#x2019; phones. Often app developers install code, called software development kits (SDKs), into their apps that sends users\u0026#x2019; location data to companies in exchange for the developer receiving payment. Sometimes app users don\u0026#x2019;t know that their phone\u0026#x2014;be that via a prayer app, or a weather app\u0026#x2014;is collecting and sending location data to third parties, let alone some of the more dangerous use cases that Motherboard has reported on, [including transferring data to U.S. military contractors](https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x). Planned Parenthood is not the organization performing the data collection nor benefiting from it financially.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de1\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":7,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"SafeGraph then repackages that location data and other data into various products. On Tuesday \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/m7vymn/cdc-tracked-phones-location-data-curfews\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMotherboard reported that the CDC bought $420,000 worth of SafeGraph data\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e for a laundry list of COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 use cases. Google \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ebanned SafeGraph from the Google Play Store in June\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":507,\"wordscount\":81,\"text\":\"SafeGraph then repackages that location data and other data into various products. On Tuesday [Motherboard reported that the CDC bought $420,000 worth of SafeGraph data](https://www.vice.com/en/article/m7vymn/cdc-tracked-phones-location-data-curfews) for a laundry list of COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 use cases. Google [banned SafeGraph from the Google Play Store in June](https://www.vice.com/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence).\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de2\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":8,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"SafeGraph classifies \\\"Planned Parenthood\\\" as a \\\"brand\\\" that can be tracked, and the data Motherboard purchased includes more than 600 Planned Parenthood locations in the United States. The data included a week's worth of location data for those locations in mid-April. SafeGraph calls the location data product Patterns. In total, the data cost just over $160. Not all Planned Parenthood locations offer abortion services. But Motherboard verified that some facilities included in the purchased dataset do.\u0026nbsp;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":514,\"wordscount\":77,\"text\":\"SafeGraph classifies \\\"Planned Parenthood\\\" as a \\\"brand\\\" that can be tracked, and the data Motherboard purchased includes more than 600 Planned Parenthood locations in the United States. The data included a week's worth of location data for those locations in mid-April. SafeGraph calls the location data product \u0026#x201c;Patterns.\u0026#x201d; In total, the data cost just over $160. Not all Planned Parenthood locations offer abortion services. But Motherboard verified that some facilities included in the purchased dataset do.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de3\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":9,\"role\":\"article\",\"site\":\"vice\",\"locale\":\"en_us\",\"web_id\":\"m7vymn\",\"display\":\"inline\",\"article_id\":\"62703582ac772b009b350675\",\"article\":{\"id\":\"62703582ac772b009b350675\",\"body\":\"\u003cp\u003eThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) bought access to location data harvested from tens of millions of phones in the United States to perform analysis of compliance with curfews, track patterns of people visiting K-12 schools, and specifically monitor the effectiveness of policy in the Navajo Nation, according to CDC documents obtained by Motherboard. The documents also show that although the CDC used COVID-19 as a reason to buy access to the data more quickly, it intended to use it for more-general CDC purposes.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eLocation data is information on a devices location sourced from the phone, which can then show where a person lives, works, and where they went. The sort of data the CDC bought was aggregatedmeaning it was designed to follow trends that emerge from the movements of groups of peoplebut researchers have repeatedly raised concerns with how location data can be deanonymized and used to track specific people.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe documents reveal the expansive plan the CDC had last year to use location data from a highly controversial data broker. SafeGraph, the company the CDC paid $420,000 for access to one year of data, includes Peter Thiel and the former head of Saudi intelligence among its investors. Google \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ebanned the company from the Play Store\u003c/a\u003e in June.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp class=\\\"article__blockquote\\\"\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cb\u003eDo you work in the location data industry? We'd love to hear from you. Using a non-work phone or computer, you can contact Joseph Cox securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, Wickr on josephcox, OTR chat on\u003ca href=\\\"mailto:jfcox@jabber.ccc.de\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ejfcox@jabber.ccc.de\u003c/a\u003e, or email\u003ca href=\\\"mailto:joseph.cox@vice.com\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ejoseph.cox@vice.com\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe CDC used the data for monitoring curfews, with the documents saying that SafeGraphs data has been critical for ongoing response efforts, such as hourly monitoring of activity in curfew zones or detailed counts of visits to participating pharmacies for vaccine monitoring. The documents date from 2021.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eZach Edwards, a cybersecurity researcher who closely follows the data marketplace, told Motherboard in an online chat after reviewing the documents: The CDC seems to have purposefully created an open-ended list of use cases, which included monitoring curfews, neighbor-to-neighbor visits, visits to churches, schools and pharmacies, and also a variety of analysis with this data specifically focused on violence. (The document doesnt stop at churches; it mentions places of worship.)\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eMotherboard obtained the documents through a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request with the CDC.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe documents contain a long list of what the CDC describes as 21 different potential CDC use cases for data. They include:\u003c/p\u003e \u003cul\u003e\u003cli\u003eTrack patterns of those visiting K-12 schools by the school and compare to 2019; compare with epi metrics [Environmental Performance Index] if possible.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eExamination of the correlation of mobility patterns data and rise in COVID-19 cases [...] Movement restrictions (Border closures, inter-regional and nigh curfews) to show compliance.\u003c/li\u003e\u003cli\u003eExamination of the effectiveness of public policy on [the] Navajo Nation.\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e \u003cp\u003eAt the start of the pandemic, cellphone location data was seen as a potentially useful tool. Multiple media organizations, including the \u003ci\u003eNew York Times\u003c/i\u003e, used location data provided by companies in the industry to show \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/05/06/opinion/coronavirus-us-reopen.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ewhere people were traveling to once lockdowns started to lift\u003c/a\u003e, or highlight that \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/04/03/us/coronavirus-stay-home-rich-poor.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003epoorer communities were unable to shelter in place as much as richer ones\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic as a whole has been a flashpoint in a broader culture war, with conservatives and anti-vaccine groups protesting government mask and vaccine mandates. They've also expressed a specific paranoia that vaccine passports would be used as a tracking or surveillance tool, framing vaccine refusal as a civil liberties issue. Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s Children's Health Defense, one of the more influential and monied anti-vaccine groups in the U.S., has promoted fears that digital vaccine certificates could be used to surveil citizens. QAnon promoter Dustin Nemos wrote on Telegram in December that vaccine passports are \\\"a Trojan horse being used to create a completely new type of controlled and surveilled society in which the freedom we enjoy today will be a distant memory.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAgainst that inflamed backdrop, the use of cellphone location data for such a wide variety of tracking measures, even if effective for becoming better informed on the pandemics spread or for informing policy, is likely to be controversial. It's also likely to give anti-vaccine groups a real-world data point on which to pin their darkest warnings.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__media\\\"\u003e\u003cpicture class=\\\"article__image\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 25em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=400:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=600:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 40.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=650:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=975:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 53.125em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=850:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=1275:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 65.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=1050:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(min-width: 65.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=1050:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1651520756653-cdc-uses.png\\\" alt=\\\"cdc-uses.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/picture\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"article__image-caption\\\"\u003eA screenshot of the use cases proposed by the CDC. Image: Motherboard.\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe procurement documents say that This is an URGENT COVID-19 PR [procurement request], and asks for the purchase to be expedited.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBut some of the use cases are not explicitly linked to the COVID-19 pandemic. One reads Research points of interest for physical activity and chronic disease prevention such as visits to parks, gyms, or weight management businesses.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eAnother section of the document elaborates on the location datas use for non-COVID-19related programs.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eCDC also plans to use mobility data and services acquired through this acquisition to support non-COVID-19 programmatic areas and public health priorities across the agency, including but not limited to travel to parks and green spaces, physical activity and mode of travel, and population migration before, during, and after natural disasters, it reads. The mobility data obtained under this contract will be available for CDC agency-wide use and will support numerous CDC priorities.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe CDC did not respond to multiple emails requesting comment on which use cases it deployed SafeGraph data for.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph is part of the ballooning location industry, and SafeGraph has \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.npr.org/2020/05/01/849161820/mobile-phone-data-show-more-americans-are-leaving-their-homes-despite-orders\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003epreviously shared datasets containing 18 million cellphones from the United States\u003c/a\u003e. The documents say this acquisition is for data that is geographically representative, i.e., derived from at least 20 million active cellphone users per day across the United States.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eGenerally, companies in this industry ask, or pay, app developers to include location data gathering code in their apps. The location data then funnels up to companies that may resell the raw location data outright or package it into products.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__embed article__embed--vice\\\" data-related-article=\\\"true\\\" data-children-count=\\\"0\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe src=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/embed/article/5db4ad/embed\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" style=\\\"border:0px none;margin:0px\\\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph sells both. On the developed product side, SafeGraph has several different products. Places concerns points of interest (POIs) such as where particular stores or buildings are located. Patterns is based on mobile phone location data that can show for how long people visit a location, and Where they came from and Where else they go, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.safegraph.com/products/patterns\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eaccording to SafeGraphs website\u003c/a\u003e. More recently SafeGraph has started offering aggregated transaction data, showing how much consumers typically spend at specific locations, under the Spend product. SafeGraph sells its products to a wide range of industries, such as real estate, insurance, and advertising. These products include aggregated data on movements and spends, rather than the location of specific devices. Motherboard previously bought a set of SafeGraph location data for $200. The data was aggregated, meaning it was not supposed to pinpoint the movements of specific devices and hence people, but at the time, Edwards said, \\\"In my opinion the SafeGraph data is way beyond any safe thresholds [around anonymity].\\\" Edwards pointed to a search result in SafeGraphs data portal that displayed data related to a specific doctors office, showing how finely tuned the companys data can be. Theoretically, an attacker could use that data to then attempt to unmask the specific users, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nature.com/articles/srep01376\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003esomething which researchers have repeatedly demonstrated is possible\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn January 2019, the Illinois Department of Transportation bought such data from SafeGraph that related to over 5 million phones, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2021/08/illinois-bought-invasive-phone-location-data-banned-broker-safegraph\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eactivist organization the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) previously found\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe CDC documents show that the agency bought access to SafeGraphs U.S. Core Place Data, Weekly Patterns Data, and Neighborhood Patterns Data. That last product includes information such as home dwelling time, and is aggregated by state and census block.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph offers visitor data at the Census Block Group level that allows for extremely accurate insights related to age, gender, race, citizenship status, income, and more, one of the CDC documents reads.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__embed article__embed--vice\\\" data-related-article=\\\"true\\\" data-children-count=\\\"0\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe src=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/embed/article/jgqm5x/embed\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" style=\\\"border:0px none;margin:0px\\\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eBoth SafeGraph and the CDC have previously touched on their partnership, but not in the detail that is revealed in the documents. The CDC \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/mm6935a2.htm?s_cid=mm6935a2_x#contribAff\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003epublished a study in September 2020\u003c/a\u003e which looked at whether people around the country were following stay-at-home orders, which appeared to use SafeGraph data.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.safegraph.com/blog/safegraph-provides-cdc-fed-and-1000-organizations-with-data-to-fight-the-covid-19-crisis\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eSafeGraph wrote in a blog post in April 2020\u003c/a\u003e that To play our part in the fight against the COVID-19 health crisisand its devastating impact on the global economywe decided to expand our program further, making our foot traffic data free for nonprofit organizations and government agencies at the local, state, and federal level. Multiple location data companies touted their data as a potential mitigation to the pandemic during its peak in the United States, and provided data to government and media organizations.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eA year later, the CDC purchased access to the data because SafeGraph no longer wanted to provide it for free, according to the documents. The Data Use Agreement for the in-kind provided data was set to expire on March 31, 2021, the documents add. The data was still important to access as the U.S. opened up, the CDC argued in the documents.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eCDC has interest in continued access to this mobility data as the country opens back up. This data is used by several teams/groups in the response and have been resulting in deeper insights into the pandemic as it pertains to human behavior, one section reads.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eResearchers at the EFF separately obtained documents concerning the CDCs purchase of similar location data products from a company called Cubeiq as well as the SafeGraph documents. The EFF shared those documents with Motherboard. They showed that the CDC also asked to speed up the purchase of Cubeiqs data because of COVID-19, and intended to use it for non-COVID-19 purposes. The documents also listed the same potential use-cases for Cubeiqs data as in the SafeGraph documents.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eGoogle \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/5db4ad/google-bans-safegraph-former-saudi-intelligence\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ebanned SafeGraph from its Google Play Store in June\u003c/a\u003e. This meant that any app developers using SafeGraphs code had to remove it from their apps, or face having their app removed from the store. It is not entirely clear how effective this ban has been: SafeGraph has \u003ca href=\\\"https://qz.com/1934587/who-is-safegraph-the-company-giving-your-location-data-to-covid-researchers/\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003epreviously said it obtains location data via Veraset\u003c/a\u003e, a spin-off company which interfaces with the app developers.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph did not respond to multiple requests for comment.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cb\u003eSubscribe to our cybersecurity podcast,\u003ca href=\\\"https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/cyber/id1441708044?mt=2\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eCYBER\u003c/a\u003e. Subscribe to\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.twitch.tv/motherboardtv\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eour new Twitch channel\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"__using_components\":false,\"suggested_tweet\":null,\"dek\":\"Newly released documents showed the CDC planned to use phone location SafeGraph calculates where it believes visitors to a location live to the census block level. SafeGraph does this by analyzing where a phone is commonly located overnight, [the company\u0026#x2019;s documentation suggests](https://docs.safegraph.com/docs/monthly-patterns#section-determining-home-location).\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de6\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":12,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"SafeGraphs data is aggregated, meaning it isnt explicitly specifying where a certain device moved to. Instead, it focuses on the movements of groups of devices. But researchers have repeatedly \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nature.com/articles/srep01376\\\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ewarned about the possibilities of unmasking individuals\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e contained in allegedly anonymized datasets.\u0026nbsp;\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":369,\"wordscount\":55,\"text\":\"SafeGraph\u0026#x2019;s data is aggregated, meaning it isn\u0026#x2019;t explicitly specifying where a certain device moved to. Instead, it focuses on the movements of groups of devices. But researchers have repeatedly [warned about the possibilities of unmasking individuals](https://www.nature.com/articles/srep01376) contained in allegedly anonymized datasets.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de7\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":13,\"role\":\"body\",\"html\":\"Sections of the SafeGraph dataset Motherboard purchased handle a very small number of devices per record, theoretically making deanonymization of those people easier. Some had just four or five devices visiting that location, with SafeGraph filtering the data by whether the person used an Android or an iOS device as well.\",\"dropcap\":false,\"charscount\":323,\"wordscount\":51,\"text\":\"Sections of the SafeGraph dataset Motherboard purchased handle a very small number of devices per record, theoretically making deanonymization of those people easier. Some had just four or five devices visiting that location, with SafeGraph filtering the data by whether the person used an Android or an iOS device as well.\"},{\"id\":\"62715c7354632c009a556de8\",\"version\":\"1\",\"position\":14,\"role\":\"article\",\"site\":\"vice\",\"locale\":\"en_us\",\"web_id\":\"5db4ad\",\"display\":\"inline\",\"article_id\":\"61141ab24e58910095558385\",\"article\":{\"id\":\"61141ab24e58910095558385\",\"body\":\"\u003cp\u003eGoogle has banned SafeGraph, a location data firm whose investors include a former head of Saudi intelligence, Motherboard has learned. The ban means that any apps working with SafeGraph had to remove the offending location gathering code from their apps. SafeGraph markets its data to government entities and a wide range of industries, but it also sells the data on the open market to essentially anyone.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe news signals Google's continued crackdown on location data firms who sometimes, in violation of Google's policies, pay app developers to include their data harvesting code and then sell the collected data to companies or government agencies.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"They are willing to sell extremely fine-grained data and anyone with a credit card can start buying it,\\\" Zach Edwards, a researcher who has closely followed the supply chain of various sources of data, told Motherboard in an email last year, when both he and Motherboard were separately investigating SafeGraph.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp class=\\\"article__blockquote\\\"\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cb\u003eDo you work at SafeGraph or are you a customer? Did you used to work there, or know anything else about the location data industry? We'd love to hear from you. Using a non-work phone or computer, you can contact Joseph Cox securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, Wickr on josephcox, or emailjoseph.cox@vice.com.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph collected at least some of its location data by having app developers embed the company's code, or software development kit (SDK), into their own apps. Those apps would then track the physical location of their users, which SafeGraph would repackage and then sell to other parties. Google confirmed to Motherboard it told app developers in early June they had seven days to remove SafeGraph's SDK from their apps. If they didn't do this, Google told Motherboard the apps may face enforcement. This can mean removal from the Play Store itself.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBeyond its own data, SafeGraph also offers customers the chance to buy related data sets from other providers to enrich the location information, such as the names of property owners in the U.S.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eLast year Motherboard bought a small set of data from SafeGraph for around $200 to test how easy it was to obtain and to verify the sort of information it contained. It included a list of points of interest for the area we bought data for, and other information such as the specific next point of interest visitors then went to. For example, one line showed the people who went to The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints then visited a list of particular convenience stores.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"In my opinion the SafeGraph data is way beyond any safe thresholds [around anonymity],\\\" Edwards said last year when Motherboard showed him the data. Academics and journalists \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/pkbxp8/grindr-location-data-priest-weaponization-app\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ehave repeatedly found how it is possible\u003c/a\u003e to deanonymize specific people in sets of location data. In his own test, Edwards pointed to a search result on the SafeGraph portal that showed data related to a specific, small doctor's clinic, demonstrating how finely SafeGraph's data can target particular locations.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eLast year, the New York Times \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/05/06/opinion/coronavirus-us-reopen.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eused SafeGraph data\u003c/a\u003e (and data from other location data brokers) to create maps that showed where people were spending their time after coronavirus lockdowns were loosened. It attempted to estimate how crowded various restaurants, gyms, and coffee shops were and how dangerous they could be. At the time, Motherboard asked the Times why it felt comfortable using SafeGraph data considering that its own reporters earlier showed how it could be used to violate peoples privacy. \\\"Were confident that our use of this data across news and opinion was responsible,\\\" a New York Times spokesperson said. \\\"The data used in [two articles that used location data] is aggregated, and did not include individualized location data. As you note, both the\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/12/10/business/location-data-privacy-apps.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003enewsroom\u003c/a\u003eand\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/12/19/opinion/location-tracking-cell-phone.html\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eopinion\u003c/a\u003esection have done in-depth investigations showing the dangers of allowing companies to sell individualized location data. In both cases the data used in those investigations was securely stored during the reporting process and permanently erased.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__embed article__embed--vice\\\" data-related-article=\\\"true\\\" data-children-count=\\\"0\\\"\u003e\u003ciframe src=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/embed/article/jgqm5x/embed\\\" frameborder=\\\"0\\\" style=\\\"border:0px none;margin:0px\\\" allowfullscreen\u003e\u003c/iframe\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eOn its website \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.safegraph.com/about\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eSafeGraph says\u003c/a\u003e \\\"We believe places data should be open for all.\\\" In April 2017, Turki bin Faisal Al Saud, the former head of Saudi Arabias intelligence agency, \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.crunchbase.com/person/turki-bin-faisal-al-saud\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003einvested in SafeGraph as part of a $16 million Series A funding round\u003c/a\u003e. \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.safegraph.com/blog/safegraph-raises-16-million-series-a\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eSafeGraph said it had\u003c/a\u003e \\\"assembled the deepest policy thinkers.\\\" Beyond Faisal Al Saud, SafeGraph said it had enlisted the help of former U.S. House Majority Leader Eric Cantor, author Sam Harris, Meghan O'Sullivan who ran Iraq and Afghanistan policy under President George Bush, former Deputy Chief of Staff to President Obama Mona Sutphen, and former German Minister of Defense Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, among others. Peter Thiel is \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.businessinsider.com/safegraph-pitch-deck-technology-startup-peter-thiel-2021-3\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ealso an investor in the company\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph was one of the many location data firms that jumped on the opportunity to sell their gathered data to help counter the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. SafeGraph's users included the CDC and at least one county health department, according to documents and online records reviewed by Motherboard.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\\\"LICENSE PERIOD: Minimum of 1 year or until COVID-19 (Coronavirus) global response has subsided,\\\" a data license agreement between SafeGraph and the County of Santa Clara, obtained by Motherboard through a public records act request, reads. In April, the CDC paid SafeGraph $420,000 for \\\"data gathering and reporting,\\\" according to public procurement records.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv class=\\\"article__media\\\"\u003e\u003cpicture class=\\\"article__image\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 25em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=400:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=600:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 40.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=650:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=975:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 53.125em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=850:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=1275:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(max-width: 65.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=1050:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003csource media=\\\"(min-width: 65.625em)\\\" srcset=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=1050:*, https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png?resize=1575:* 2x\\\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\\\"https://video-images.vice.com/_uncategorized/1628707892933-safegraph-agreement.png\\\" alt=\\\"safegraph-agreement.png\\\"\u003e\u003c/picture\u003e\u003cdiv class=\\\"article__image-caption\\\"\u003eA screenshot of the agreement between the County of Santa Clara and SafeGraph. Image: Motherboard.\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cp\u003eIt's unclear if SafeGraph is still collecting any data from Android devices after Google's ban. Earlier this month \u003ci\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/location-data-broker-x-mode-to-be-bought-by-digital-envoy-11628074800\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eThe Wall Street Journal \u003c/a\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003ca href=\\\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/location-data-broker-x-mode-to-be-bought-by-digital-envoy-11628074800\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ereported\u003c/a\u003e that a similar company called X-Mode, which \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/g5bjpx/apple-google-x-mode-xmode-app-stores\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eGoogle banned\u003c/a\u003e after \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqm5x/us-military-location-data-xmode-locate-x\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003eMotherboard revealed\u003c/a\u003e it collected information from a Muslim prayer app and has U.S. military contractors among its customers, has found a workaround to still harvest location information from apps. Now, X-Mode provides tools to individual app developers to collect the location data themselves, who then pass it over to X-Mode, making it arguably harder for Google, researchers, journalists, or regulators to detect abuses.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eKeith Chu, communications director for the office of Senator Ron Wyden, told Motherboard that when it urged Apple and Google to take action against X-Mode following Motherboard's reporting, the office also flagged SafeGraph to the tech giants. Chu added Wyden's office tried to contact SafeGraph in June, July, and twice in August last year, but never received a response.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eIn a statement, Wyden said this enforcement was the right move by Google, but Google and Apple \\\"need to do more than play whack-a-mole with apps that sell Americans location information. These companies need a real plan to protect users privacy and safety from these malicious apps.\\\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eGoogle also \u003ca href=\\\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/dy8eba/google-predicio-ban-muslim-prayer-app\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ebanned another location firm called Predicio\u003c/a\u003e after Motherboard's reporting.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eSafeGraph did not respond to multiple requests for comment on its ban from the Google Play Store.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003eUpdate: This article has been updated to include more specific use cases of SafeGraph data.\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003ci\u003e\u003cb\u003eSubscribe to our cybersecurity podcast CYBER,\u003ca href=\\\"https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/cyber/id1441708044\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/b\u003e\u003c/i\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\",\"__using_components\":false,\"suggested_tweet\":null,\"dek\":\"SafeGraph sells smartphone location data to essentially anyone. Google banned the company in readabilityObject.title: Data Broker Is Selling Location Data of People Who Visit Abortion Clinics
readabilityObject.content:
Image: The Washington Post/Contributor

Hacking. Disinformation. Surveillance. CYBER is Motherboard's podcast and reporting on the dark underbelly of the internet.

A location data firm is selling information related to visits to clinics that provide abortions including Planned Parenthood facilities, showing where groups of people visiting the locations came from, how long they stayed there, and where they then went afterwards, according to sets of the data purchased by Motherboard.

The data sale is obviously more important in the context of a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion in which Justice Alito indicated that the court is ready to repeal the decision in Roe v. Wade, the decades-old precedent that has provided federal protections to those seeking an abortion. If that draft does become a formal decision, it would immediately fully or partly ban abortion rights in at least 13 states.

How data collecting intersects with abortion rights, or the lack thereof, is likely to gather more attention in the wake of the draft. The country may also see an increase in vigilante activity or forms of surveillance and harassment against those seeking or providing abortions. With this aggregated location data available to anyone on the open market, customers could include anti-abortion vigilantes as well. Anti-abortion groups are already fairly adept at using novel technology for their goals. In 2016, an advertising CEO who worked with anti-abortion and Christian groups sent targeted advertisements to women sitting in Planned Parenthood clinics in an attempt to change their decision around getting an abortion. The sale of the location data raises questions around why companies are selling data based on abortion clinics specifically, and whether they should introduce more safeguards around the purchase of that information, if be selling it at all.

It's bonkers dangerous to have abortion clinics and then let someone buy the census tracks where people are coming from to visit that abortion clinic, Zach Edwards, a cybersecurity researcher who closely tracks the data selling marketplace, told Motherboard in an online chat after reviewing the data. This is how you dox someone traveling across state lines for abortionshow you dox clinics providing this service.

Do you work in the location data industry or how know else the data is being used? We'd love to hear from you. Using a non-work phone or computer, you can contact Joseph Cox securely on Signal on +44 20 8133 5190, Wickr on josephcox, OTR chat on jfcox@jabber.ccc.de, or email joseph.cox@vice.com.

In the wake of a near-total abortion ban in Texas, for example, people in Texas seeking abortions have increasingly had to travel to other states where abortion access is easier to get the care they need. With Roe set to fall, people seeking abortions who live in conservative states and can afford to are likely to start traveling to get an abortion. Location data could play into whether and how that travel is identified, making it even more urgent for regulators and lawmakers to consider how location data is collected, used, and sold.

The company selling the data is SafeGraph. SafeGraph ultimately obtains location data from ordinary apps installed on peoples phones. Often app developers install code, called software development kits (SDKs), into their apps that sends users location data to companies in exchange for the developer receiving payment. Sometimes app users dont know that their phonebe that via a prayer app, or a weather appis collecting and sending location data to third parties, let alone some of the more dangerous use cases that Motherboard has reported on, including transferring data to U.S. military contractors. Planned Parenthood is not the organization performing the data collection nor benefiting from it financially.

SafeGraph then repackages that location data and other data into various products. On Tuesday Motherboard reported that the CDC bought $420,000 worth of SafeGraph data for a laundry list of COVID-19 and non-COVID-19 use cases. Google banned SafeGraph from the Google Play Store in June.

SafeGraph classifies "Planned Parenthood" as a "brand" that can be tracked, and the data Motherboard purchased includes more than 600 Planned Parenthood locations in the United States. The data included a week's worth of location data for those locations in mid-April. SafeGraph calls the location data product Patterns. In total, the data cost just over $160. Not all Planned Parenthood locations offer abortion services. But Motherboard verified that some facilities included in the purchased dataset do. 

Motherboard also searched the SafeGraph website for Family Planning, which returned a relevant result of Family Planning Centers that people could then buy data related to.

SafeGraphs Patterns data aims to answer questions like how often people visit, how long they stay, where they came from, where else they go, and more, according to SafeGraphs website. SafeGraph calculates where it believes visitors to a location live to the census block level. SafeGraph does this by analyzing where a phone is commonly located overnight, the companys documentation suggests.

SafeGraphs data is aggregated, meaning it isnt explicitly specifying where a certain device moved to. Instead, it focuses on the movements of groups of devices. But researchers have repeatedly warned about the possibilities of unmasking individuals contained in allegedly anonymized datasets. 

Sections of the SafeGraph dataset Motherboard purchased handle a very small number of devices per record, theoretically making deanonymization of those people easier. Some had just four or five devices visiting that location, with SafeGraph filtering the data by whether the person used an Android or an iOS device as well.

On the data showing where people traveled to a certain clinic based on their census block, potentially across state borders, Edwards said SafeGraph is going to be the weapon of choice for anti-choice radicals attempting to target out of state clinics providing medical care. Missouri is considering a law to make it illegal to aid or abet abortions in other states.

Tracking visitors to abortion clinics has long been a staple in showing the threat posed by location data. In a 2018 investigation, The New York Times took location data and followed multiple people inside it, and unmasked some of those. One of the people followed visited a Planned Parenthood facility, according to the report.

Recently, a Christian-focused outlet The Pillar published a piece that used location data to track the movements of a specific priest and then outed him publicly as potentially gay without his consent.

Planned Parenthood did not respond to a request for comment. SafeGraph did not respond to a request for comment either, which included the specific question of whether the company would continue to sell location data related to abortion clinics.

Subscribe to our cybersecurity podcast, CYBER. Subscribe to our new Twitch channel.

ORIGINAL REPORTING ON EVERYTHING THAT MATTERS IN YOUR INBOX.
